nodes.bodyText:
I think it's easier to understand if we do not use the abbreviation sim as function name.
When scanning the lines quickly (and without deep knowledge about the domain), naming this simulate would make it a bit easier to reason about the code.
This comment is not correct anymore ;)

nodes.bodyText:
Wouldn't Value| null be sufficient here?
const [value, setValue] = useState<Value | null>(null);
What does this do? It is retrieving HTMLElements and changing properties - why? Were there no React Components for that available?

Looks like find() could be used here. But that's not a big deal here.
I would at least rename i: Sound like a name for an index, but it contains the value of the array. landscape would be much better here.
I remember having used this before myself. Did you check how it behaves when you scale the page? I guess you did :)
no it doesnt work properly on scaling, i'll sit down with daniel tomorrow and will talk with him abit about material ui and our requirements and goals for our styling
My personal preference: it does not hurt to just use "landscape". I had to scroll to understand what "l" stood for ;)
yeah should change that, leftover from old app
Out of interest: I saw that this is used in a Button. Does the button handle the returned Promise on click?
This is a big component. The landscape could maybe be moved to an own component.
we could move it into a layout component (and maybe work with layout components in all components?)

This could move to the LandscapeContext and in general REST calls could go to the corresponding contexts. By doing so, the components have less responsibilities and can concentrate on doing what they know how to do. In this case Home is really big already (see below), but still, even if it was smaller, it should only know how to do "Home" :)

See my comment above, this is a case where the REST call logic could go into the context to make the Landscape component have less responsibilities. The LandscpaeContext would deliver the landscapes  ("getLandscapes" from above) and reload them (this reload) and you would only implement it once.

yeah i wasnt happy with that either, didnt have much experience with context, i'll try it,
thanks for the recommendation
I guess this can be removed.
Can also be removed.
What's t1``and t2`? The parameters would benefit from a better name and/or a type.
@bonndan
Looks like a leftover.
Yes, the code is unused at the moment.
Are there landscapes without name or identifier?

the landscape interface is something that we have to take a look on together, i didnt know what was really necessary and what not so i just made (almost) everything optional for now that could be made optional
Landscapes must have identifiers and will very like have a name. The rest is indeed optional.
Is App_old a renaming accident?
Nice!

I would advise you not to use Date, if you have a choice.
The new, immutable date types like ZonedDateTime  or LocalDateTime are much better.
Fixed in 348b9bf

nodes.bodyText: Do you close the outputStream if an Exception occurrs during the flush? Better use try-with-resources for the AutoCloseable OutputStream :) (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56112598/proper-way-to-close-an-autocloseable)
But, for ByteArrayOutputStream, close() and flush() do nothing (check out the implementation). This try-catch-block is not necessary. I wonder now, what the exception message was intended for?
